content.title: Femoropopliteal Occlusive Disease
content.definition: Femoropopliteal occlusive disease is atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the superficial femoral and/or popliteal arteries, the most common location for peripheral arterial disease, typically presenting as calf claudication.

epidemiology.most_common_location: SFA is the most frequently affected artery in PAD
epidemiology.prevalence: Involved in up to 90% of patients with PAD
epidemiology.natural_history: Progresses more commonly than aortoiliac disease

superficial_femoral_artery.course: From CFA bifurcation through adductor canal (Hunter's canal)
superficial_femoral_artery.adductor_hiatus: Site of highest plaque burden (biomechanical stress)

popliteal_artery.prone_to: Both occlusive disease and aneurysm formation

tasc_classification.tasc_d: CTO >20cm, chronic total occlusion of popliteal and trifurcation

claudication.pattern: Reproducible at same distance, relieved with rest

clinical_presentation.critical_limb_ischemia: Rest pain, tissue loss when combined with tibial disease

diagnosis.exercise_abi: Unmasks disease with normal resting ABI

endovascular.drug_coated_balloon: Preferred for SFA - better patency than plain balloon

conduit.prosthetic: PTFE or Dacron - inferior patency above knee

learning_objectives: Apply TASC classification to treatment planning
Select appropriate conduit for infrainguinal bypass
clinical_pearls: SFA is the most commonly affected artery in PAD
Adductor canal/Hunter's canal is site of highest plaque burden
Drug-coated balloons have improved SFA endovascular outcomes
Autogenous vein (GSV) is best conduit for bypass
pedagogical.board_yield: HIGH - most common location for PAD
